Evia's core argument is that if technical communicators are trained with prin<t0/>ciples of rhetorical problem solving and computational thinking, they can create structured content in lightweight workflows with XML, HTML5, and Markdown designed to reduce the learning curve associated with DITA and similar authoring methodologies.

Evia's work is firmly situated in what is starting to be called the shift from the “craftsman model” of Technical Communication to the “Component Content Management model.” This shift has come about as a result of the ways that new technologies like XML DITA, single-source authoring environments, and Content Management Systems have changed the ways that technical writers deliver information to audiences (or what we would now call “users”).
